body_text.text: messages, assemble the subunits, and incorporate functional AChRs into their surface membrane. The channel properties of the cloned AChRs can be studied with patch clamp technology. Previous studies have shown that the AChRs retain their unique channel properties despite their foreign environment 22. When oocytes were injected with a mixture of c~-, 13-, y-and ~5-subunit mRNAs, they expressed channels that had the same prolonged open time and low conductance characteristic of AChRs in embryonic bovine muscle (Figs 3A and B) . Conversely, oocytes injected with ~-, I]-, ~-and 5-subunit mRNAs expressed AChRs with the brief open time and high conductance typical of channels in adult endplates (Figs 3C and D) . Further experiments showed that the subunit switch also can account for a developmental change in the voltage dependence of AChR channel open time. In this context it is interesting to note that previous work illustrated the importance of the ~-and 5-subunits in regulating AChR gating properties 22. Now two more subunits can be added to the list.

These data suggest that a developmental change in gene expression directly effects the changes in AChR channel properties in bovine muscle. It seems likely that this is a consequence of innervation. In the rat, denervation at birth inhibits the appearance of adult-type channels TM, suggesting that innervation might promote the expression of a rat e-subunit mRNA and inhibit that of y-subunit mRNA. However, the story may be more complicated. First, it is possible that innervation differentially regulates yand ¢-subunit mRNA stability rather than level of expression. Second, the amount of bovine ~-subunit mRNA falls to a low, though detectable, level at postnatal stages. The significance of this decrease in 6-subunit message production remains unclear, but one possibility is that the 6-subunit is also replaced. Finally, recent experiments in the rat indicate that adult-type AChR channels can appear more quickly at developing endplates than new AChRs are thought to be inserted into the membrane 23. This suggests that rats may have an additional mechanism for regulating channel open time.
An important extension of this work will be to study the levels and distribution of y-and c-subunit mRNAs in denervated adult muscle.

Denervating adult rat muscles leads to a massive increase in the synthesis and incorporation of AChRs with embryonic-type channel properties into extrajunctional regions 4'6. Despite this, the endplate region continues to synthesize and incorporate AChRs with adulttype channels 17. Assuming that rat embryonic-and adult-type AChRs also differ in their subunit composition, this suggests that endplate nuclei are producing e-subunit mRNA, while extrajunctional nuclei within the same cytoplasm are producing y-subunit mRNA. This could be tested with insitu hybridization of y-and e-subunit cDNA probes. The results will have important implications for the regulation of AChR gene expression.
of sclerosis: where does truth lie?
body_text.section: Viral

body_text.text: One of the oldest theories of multiple sclerosis (MS) is that a viral infection, perhaps encountered early in life, may initiate the disease process that is expressed clinically some 5-20 years later 1. A unique virus or group of viruses has not been unequivocally linked to MS in spite of intensive investigation, and the viral theory has yielded center stage to immunological theories in recent years. However, recent epidemiological 2'3 and virological 4 studies once again raise the question of a specific viral cause of MS, and make this an opportune time to review our knowledge in this controversial area.
body_text.section: Viral

body_text.text: Multiple sclerosis affects 250 000 or more persons in the United States.
body_text.section: Multiple sclerosis as a clinical disease

body_text.text: Clinical illness becomes apparent in three-quarters of cases before the age of 40 and is nearly twice as common in women as in men. The lesions, found throughout the brain, optic nerves and spinal cord, are characterized by patchy inflammation and demyelination with eventual gliotic scarring. Neurological signs may include disturbed gait, weakness, or paralysis; double vision, nystagmus, and partial or complete blindness; slurred speech; sensory disorders (particularly paresthesias); cognitive deficit; and bladder, bowel, and sexual difficulties. Definitive diagnosis requires the demonstration that CNS lesions are disseminated in space and time. There is no specific laboratory test, though evoked potentials and imaging techniques may contribute to the demonstra-(~' ) 1986, Elsevier Science Publishers B V • Amsterdam I)]7g -5912/8¢~' $112 ~1 tion of lesions. MS is highly variable from individual to individual and from time to time in individuals, and may have a benign, relapsing-remitting, or progressive course. The prognosis for a person with MS is nearly impossible to determine at the present time.
body_text.section: Multiple sclerosis as a clinical disease

body_text.text: The etiology of the disease remains unknown. Most investigators favor an autoimmune hypothesis, with cellular and/or humoral immune responses directed against constituents of myelin. A viral trigger may set the stage for an autoimmune response, as discussed below, but disease occurs only in individuals with an appropriate genetic make-up s . There is no current preventive or cure for MS. However, current trials of new drugs hold promise for uncovering an immunoregulatory or anti-inflammatory agent that may effectively alter the course of the disease. New drugs for symptomatic management are also promising. If a viral etiology can be identified, the possibility of developing a specific antiviral vaccine becomes relevant.
body_text.section: Multiple sclerosis as a clinical disease

body_text.text: The evidence for this view of MS is mainly epidemiological. MS occasionally is seen in epidemic form, for example in the Faroe Islands and Iceland, where MS outbreaks followed the occupation by British troops during World War II 1'6. Cook has tried to relate these epidemics to epidemics of canine distemper in the dog population 7, and has pointed to an increased incidence of MS following periodic outbreaks of distemper in Newfoundland s. However, a clear association of animals, canine distemper and MS has not been found elsewhere. Studies of monozygotic twins discordant for MS have suggested a relationship between frequency and severity of viral disease in early life and development of MS later 9. Siblings concordant for MS often get MS in the same year, even though they are of different ages, pointing to a possible common triggering agent ~°.
body_text.section: Evidence supporting a viral etiology forMS

body_text.text: The age at which viral infection occurs may be crucial in determining whether it can initiate the MS process. In the Faroes, the period of maximum susceptibility was defined as the age range of 13-26. In the twin study, the period of late childhood and adolescence was pinpointed. A recent retrospective analysis and comparison of MS patients with HLA-matched controls in Britain showed that com-mort childhood diseases (rubella, measles, mumps) had occurred at a significantly later age in the MS groupll; similar findings are reported from studies of measles in Los Angeles 12 and infectious mononucleosis in Sweden 13.
body_text.section: Evidence supporting a viral etiology forMS

body_text.text: MS prevalence rates, in the Caucasian population, increase with increasing latitude. The most persuasive documentation of this relationship is Kurtzke's case-control study of American veterans TM. The latitude effect, together with the higher prevalence of MS in individuals of higher socioeconomic status 1, is often taken as supporting the importance of environmental (presumably infectious) factors in MS, and a comparison is made with poliomyelitis, in which similar relationships are observed. Migration data (between high and low prevalence areas) again point to a critical period around puberty before which exposure to the putative environmental agent must occur 15A6. However, recent evidence from Israel is said to negate these findings, since native-born residents of Israel now appear to carry the risk of their immigrant parents for MS (high among Askenazi Jews, low among Sephardic Jews) rather than the risk of the geographical location (Israel is a low risk area) 17. Similarly, in North America, high risk MS areas are congruent with areas of Scandinavian immigration TM. These data re-emphasize the importance of genetic factors in MS that are stressed in twin and family studies as well.
body_text.section: Evidence supporting a viral etiology forMS

body_text.text: Evidence has also been presented to implicate viral infections in triggering periodic relapses of MS. In a closely followed MS population, Sibley showed that more than 25% of clinical exacerbations were associated with upper respiratory infections 19, and a similar relationship has recently been shown for sinusitis 2°. However, in both instances, there were as many positives among control (non-MS) subjects as among those with MS, and both findings require confirmation. The recent report indicating that genomic material of a retrovirus related to HTLV-I was found in cerebrospinal fluid T-cells 4 was lacking appropriate controls in patients with other neurological diseases. Thus far other laboratories have been unable to confirm the reported findings.
body_text.section: Evidence supporting a viral etiology forMS

body_text.text: The fact that no virus has been found does not mean that there is no virus. Indeed, the bulk of the epidemiological work suggests that a viral link may be vital. While it remains possible that a previously unknown 'MS virus' will be discovered, the epidemiological evidence points instead to common childhood and/or upper respiratory virus infections that precede the illness. An attempt has been made, through antibody and T-cell studies, to pin down one or more of these as a specific etiological agent. However, it has become clear that people with multiple sclerosis show elevated serum and CSF antibody titers to many viruses, and no one virus stands out as unusual in this regard, though there have been waves of enthusiasm for measles and for Epstein-Barr virus 24. These elevated titers may be more a reflection of altered immune response to virus in people with MS, than evidence that any single virus is tied to the disease. Immune complexes in the CSF have been found to contain multiple viruses 2s. The CSF also contains a polyclonal T-cell population reactive with many common viruses 26.
body_text.section: Evidence supporting a viral etiology forMS

body_text.text: A single finding involving T-ceils stands out as showing some specificity. Utermohlen and Zabriskie reported a deficit in circulating T-lymphocytes reactive with measles virus in patients with MS, using production of the iymphokine MIF as their assay 27. Recently Jacobson et al. 28 have similarly shown a striking deficit in measlesspecific cytotoxic T-cell precursors in MS. In this case, the T-cell recognition of measles was MHC class II-restricted. There was no comparable deficit in cells specific for influenza (class Irestricted) or mumps (class II-restricted) (McFarland, H., pers. commun.). There is no way of knowing at present whether this finding really implicates measles virus as such or some other antigen (e.g. of myelin) that shares epitopes with a measles antigen.
body_text.section: Evidence supporting a viral etiology forMS

body_text.text: There are three possible mechanisms through which a virus might produce the lesions of MS. Direct infection and damage of myelin-producing oligodendrocytes could result in myelin breakdown, accompanied by secondary inflammation. Alternatively, an inflammatory immunological response against virus persisting in the CNS could have a secondary demyelinating effect. A third possibility -one that carries both theoretical and experimental credenceis that viral infection results in autoimmunization against some component of white matter and gives rise to immunoiogically mediated inflammatory disease.
body_text.section: How might a virus do damage in MS ?

body_text.text: Animal models that involve viral agents provide justification for each of these possibilities. Certain mutants of the JHM strain of mouse hepatitis virus produce direct infection of oligodendrocytes in mice, and a chronic demyelinative disease 29. The Theiler's virus, on the other hand, produces a persistent CNS infection in mice and inflammatory demyelinative lesions, mediated by T-cells reactive with viral antigens 3°. Rats infected with JHM virus develop T-cell sensitization to both virus and myelin basic protein (MBP) 31, resulting in subacute and chronic inflammatory demyelination, respectively. Visna, a relapsing-remitting demyelinative disease in sheep, results from a lifelong retrovirus infection, with viral transcription and expression mainly in cells of the monocyte-macrophage series 32. Antigenic shifts in the viral envelope protein lead to relapses of the disease, which appears to be immunologically mediated. It is not clear whether a viral antigen or autoantigen is involved.
body_text.section: How might a virus do damage in MS ?

body_text.text: In man, acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (an inflammatory demyelinative disease) sometimes follows infection with enveloped viruses (measles, rubella, varicella, vaccinia) or with unidentified viruses causing upper respiratory infection, and is associated with T-cell sensitization both against virus and against MBP 33.
body_text.section: How might a virus do damage in MS ?

body_text.text: In occasional instances such acute disease may be followed by typical MS. It seems probable that the rarity with which this occurs reflects the genetic constraints determining MS susceptibility.
body_text.section: How might a virus do damage in MS ?

body_text.text: The research of the last two years appears to have provided a straightforward explanation of how viruses can cause the autoimmunization observed. There is clear-cut immunological crossreactivity based on amino acid sequence homology ('molecular mimicry') between epitopes of viral antigens and antigenic components of myelin, such as MBP and proteolipid protein (PLP). Aside from the question of immunization and its specificity, viral infection has secondary effects that are crucial for the pathogenesis of the MS lesion.
body_text.section: How might a virus do damage in MS ?

body_text.text: The T-ceU reaction with specific antigen, whether of virus or of myelin, requires the presence of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) antigens on antigen-presenting cells. Such MHC is normally not expressed on either vascular or parenchymal elements of the CNS. It is now clear that viral infection may lead directly to the expression of MHC by CNS vascular endothelial cells 36. Perhaps more significant is the release of y-interferon (IFN-y) by T-cells responding to virus. This molecule up-regulates expression of MHC class I and class II antigens, both on CNS vascular endothelium 37 and on astrocytes and other CNS elements, and permits presentation (e.g. of MBP to MBP-reactive Tcells) 3s. MHC expression has actually been demonstrated immunohistochemically on endothelium and astrocytes in and near MS lesions 39. The importance of this mechanism was established in a recent clinical trial, in which injection of IFN-~/was found to precipitate exacerbations of disease in patients with exacerbating-remitting MS 4°. These observations appear to explain how repeated viral infections, which lead to IFN-y release systemically, help to initiate the MS process and later trigger relapses of the disease.
body_text.section: How might a virus do damage in MS ?

body_text.text: A popular misconception of a viral etiology for MS is the notion that the disease itself may be transmissible or contagious 2'3. In fact, there is no evidence of this; the spouses of people with MS show concordance rates for MS no higher than those found among the general population. If any single virus is implicated, it may well be transmissible, but the disease MS will be seen as an uncommon complication. The evidence already cited makes it more probable that MS is associated with common viral diseases to which we are all exposed at some point in our lives. If this is so, the notion of developing a virus-specific vaccine for prevention of MS may not be realistic. Instead, to intervene in the MS process, we must turn our attention toward control of the immune response to the virus attack and to control of critical inflammatory mediators like IFN-y and recognition elements such as the MHC. In recent years these has been a heightened interest in finding gender differences in brain structure and function to explain presumed genderrelated differences in cognitive ability. The focus has been mainly on the question of hemispheric lateralization in cognitive processing, and in particular, visuospatial processing. The dominant theory holds that males process visuospatial information predominantly with the right hemisphere, and are thus said to be more lateralized, while females use both hemispheres, and are said to be less lateralized or more symmetrical than males. This difference in functional lateralization, or 'specialization', is viewed as an explanation for a presumed gender difference in visuospatial abilities, with males being superior to females.
body_text.section: Consquencesofa viral hypothesis forMS

body_text.text: The validity of the evidence for such gender-related differences in either cognitive functioning or hemispheric lateralization of visuospatial functioning remains highly controversial, as recent exhaustive reviews of the literature have documented 1-~. These reviews show that the body of literature on gender differences in spatial ability is seriously flawed by findings of marginal, if any, statistical significance; by conflicting results and failures of replication; by poor experimental design and lack of sufficient controls for variables; by a lack of consensus in defining the term 'spatial ability', and, thus, the function being measured by the variety of (often incomparable) tests used in different studies; and, finally, by the paucity of evidence that 'spatial ability' is a legitimate, unitary construct 1.
body_text.section: Evidence for gender-related differences in cognitive functions

body_text.text: These reviews further demonstrate that as many published studies find no gender differences as do find them. Meta-analysis of the body of studies on cognitive sex differences has found that when gender-related differences are found, they account for no more than 1-5% of the population variance, and the difference between mean scores is only one-quarter to one-half of a standard deviation 5. The variation within each sex is far greater than the variation between them. Furthermore, gender differences on a particular test can be eradicated in a single practice session t. These are not promising bases for the construction of theories of gender differences. In his review of the literature on cognitive sex differences, Hugh Fairweather concluded 'that the majority of studies reviewed here and elsewhere are both ill-thought and illperformed...
body_text.section: Evidence for gender-related differences in cognitive functions

body_text.text: We cannot pretend that we are testing a theory of sex differences, since at present none can exist.'2
body_text.section: Evidence for gender-related differences in cognitive functions

body_text.text: The further problem is that even if gender differences in hemispheric lateralization of visuospatial function were clearly demonstrated, there is no evidence that there is any correlation between hemispheric lateralization and visuospatial ability. It is equally possible that symmetrical hemispheric processing of visuospatial information is superior. In fact, so little is known
body_text.section: Evidence for gender-related differences in cognitive functions

BIBREF9.title: lmmunoregulatory Processes in Experimental Allergic Encephalomyelitis and Multiple Sclerosis

FIGREF0.text: Computerized database searching has shown shared sequences of six amino acids in hepatitis B virus (HBV) polymerase and the encephalitogenic site of MBP 34. Later studies by other workers have uncovered homologies between measles, Epstein-Barr, influenza A and B and other upper respiratory viruses and MBP. Finally, rabbits injected with 8-10 amino acid synthetic peptides of HBV make antibody cross-reactive with MBP, develop MBP-responsive peripheral blood T-cells and show histological evidence of encephalomyelitis 34. In a human case of post-infectious encephalomyelitis following rubella, Marquardt showed that individual clones of CSF T-cells were reactive with both the virus and MBP (Marquardt, P., pers. commun.). This appears to establish the validity of the molecular mimicry concept in man at the level of single cells. Lisak and Zweiman reported finding CSF T-cells reactive with MBP in acute MS 35, but this observation has not been confirmed. Comparable studies of T-cells from the white matter lesions of MS are needed but are difficult to accomplish.

TABREF0.text: Attempts to demonstrate a viral etiology forMS To date, no single virus or group of viruses has been demonstrated to be involved in multiple sclerosis. Of eleven candidate viruses that have been isolated from MS patients (these include rabies, Herpes simplex, the scrapie agent, parainfluenza virus I, the 'multiple sclerosis agent' of Carp, measles, simian virus I, chimpanzee cytomegalovirus, corona virus, SMON-like virus and tick borne encephalitis flavivirus) 21, none has stood the test of time. Nucleic acid hybridization carried out on brain sections has been reported to show the presence of measles 22 and Herpes simplex virus 23 genomic material.

TABREF1.text: to reported sex differences in the human corpus callosum as reflecting sex differences in hemispheric lateralization of visuospatial functions. The question is whether or not existing knowledge of the corpus callosum permits interpretations that relate differing cognitive functions to variations in size and shape of the callosum. The striking variations in callosal size and shape among individuals regardless of gender, when viewed in the context of a growing body of experimental findings, suggest that postnatal maturational processes of the corpus callosum are significantly affected by experience.
